As a Senior UX/UI Product Designer at Conduent, I helped lead the creation of the Conduent Automation Platform (CAP) Design System—a scalable, cross-product solution built on a foundation of modular components that brought clarity, consistency, and accessibility compliance to a fragmented enterprise ecosystem.

...modular components built with flexibility and extensibility in mind, creating a foundation for unified product experiences.

Component Architecture

We structured the system using atomic design principles, organizing components into four tiers:

  • Foundation: color tokens, typography scales, spacing systems
  • Core components: buttons, inputs, checkboxes, etc.
  • Patterns: complex UI structures like forms, data tables, navigation
  • Page templates: reusable layouts for common use cases

Each component was intentionally built with customization and variants in mind, allowing teams to address edge cases without breaking visual or functional consistency.

...accessibility compliance throughout the design system, ensuring all components met WCAG 2.1 AA standards and were usable by people with diverse abilities.

Accessibility Implementation

Accessibility wasn’t a bolt-on—it was a guiding principle from day one. We:

  • Met WCAG 2.1 AA contrast and interaction requirements
  • Supported full keyboard navigation and focus states
  • Used semantic markup and ARIA attributes to support screen readers
  • Designed responsive layouts that scaled cleanly up to 200% zoom

I also led accessibility documentation and ran cross-functional workshops to embed accessible design thinking into our process. This helped designers and engineers approach accessibility with clarity and consistency—not confusion.

The Challenge

Conduent’s product suite was grappling with serious consistency issues. Years of independent development had led to siloed products, each with its own UI patterns, visual language, and interaction quirks. This lack of cohesion slowed teams down, introduced usability challenges, and resulted in increased development time and fragmented user journeys.

...consistency issues stemming from years of independent product development across different business units and acquired companies.

System Fragmentation

During our audit, we found:

  • 12 different button styles with conflicting states
  • 8 color palettes, many of them off-brand
  • Form and layout patterns all over the map
  • Navigation that changed from app to app
  • No standardized spacing or type scale

The lack of consistency increased cognitive load for users and slowed teams down. Fixing this was more than a design task—it was a business necessity.

...increased development time, higher training costs, and accessibility concerns that needed to be addressed systematically.

Business Impact of Fragmentation

The inconsistency had a clear cost:

  • 40% longer development cycles for UI features
  • More QA hours chasing visual and functional bugs
  • Gaps in accessibility creating legal risk
  • Expensive onboarding and training
  • Eroded trust in the brand’s visual identity

Product and engineering leads were especially concerned about velocity. Teams needed a way to ship faster without sacrificing quality—or reinventing basic components every time.

The Process

We approached the CAP Design System as more than a UI toolkit—it was a strategic initiative that started with extensive research and conversations with stakeholders across product, design, and engineering. From there, I worked closely with teams to define and deliver a scalable component library that could flex across different product needs without compromising consistency.

...extensive research including competitive analysis, user interviews, and UI audits to understand both user needs and system requirements.

Research Methodology

The research phase included:

  • UI audits of key products
  • Competitive benchmarking across 8 SaaS platforms
  • Interviews with many stakeholders across design, product, and engineering
  • Workshops to align on shared use cases and pain points
  • User research to understand pain points with existing interfaces

The research provided critical insights into both the technical requirements and user needs that would drive the design system. It also helped identify priority components and patterns that would deliver the most immediate value.

...scalable component library through an iterative process that balanced standardization with the flexibility needed for diverse product requirements.

Component Design & Development

We followed a structured approach:

  1. Define design principles and system architecture
  2. Build foundational elements (color, type, spacing)
  3. Design core components with robust variant support
  4. Create usage documentation and guidelines
  5. Review with cross-functional teams
  6. Refine after implementation feedback
  7. Publish to Figma and Storybook for broad access

We used atomic design to ensure scalability: smaller elements built into patterns, then templates. Every component was usability tested and engineering-reviewed before release.

The Solution

We structured the system around three tightly integrated pillars: a comprehensive Figma library, reusable code components, and detailed documentation. This end-to-end approach helped teams design and build with confidence, ensuring consistency from concept to code.

...a comprehensive Figma library that provided designers with ready-to-use components, styles, and templates to accelerate the design process.

Figma Component Library

The library included:

  • Design tokens implemented as Figma variables
  • Core components with smart properties and variants
  • Auto-layout-based templates
  • Example screens showing components in context
  • In-component documentation for clarity

We structured everything to promote speed and flexibility—designers could drop in components and adapt them without breaking consistency.

...reusable code components that implemented the design specifications with precision, ensuring visual fidelity and functional consistency.

Code Implementation

Partnering closely with engineers, we delivered:

  • A CSS variable system using custom properties
  • Angular components mirroring the Figma library
  • IBuilt-in accessibility behavior
  • Performance-optimized, reusable code
  • Integration support for existing front-end stacks

Every component was stress-tested for responsiveness, accessibility, and browser support before being shipped to production.

...detailed documentation that provided clear guidelines, usage examples, and best practices for using the design system effectively.

System Documentation

We treated documentation as a first-class deliverable:

  • Clear guidelines for when and how to use each component
  • Accessibility dos and don’ts
  • Developer notes, code examples, and integration details
  • Decision trees to help teams pick the right UI patterns
  • A living portal (via Storybook) that served as a shared source of truth

We also baked governance and contribution rules into the documentation to keep the system sustainable and collaborative.

Results & Impact

The results spoke for themselves. The CAP Design System delivered significant business value—not just in terms of faster development and better UX, but in the way it transformed how teams collaborated. It became a shared language that brought designers and developers together, aligned efforts, and raised the bar across the board.

...significant business value with measurable improvements in development velocity, product quality, and user satisfaction.

Quantifiable Outcomes

Across four major product teams, we saw:

  • 40% faster UI development
  • 60% drop in visual/UI bugs
  • 75% faster design-to-dev handoff
  • Full WCAG 2.1 AA compliance
  • Easier cross-product onboarding for end users

...transformed how teams collaborated by creating a shared language and reference point for both designers and developers.

Cultural & Process Impact

The intangible wins were just as meaningful:

  • Tighter collaboration between design and dev
  • Reduced design review time (thanks to clear standards)
  • Easier onboarding for new team members
  • A shared design vocabulary that built trust and alignment
  • More space to focus on the experience—not the pixels

The CAP Design System didn’t just solve consistency issues—it helped design become a strategic asset for the business. It showed that thoughtful systems thinking could reduce friction, speed up delivery, and raise the quality bar across the board.

title: Enterprise Product Design
alt: Cover image for case study showing examples of search sketch, dashboard, and workflow UI
content:
Overview

3+
Years of Development
Low-Code
Automation Platform
Global
Cross-Functional Teams

As a Senior Product Designer at Conduent, I helped create a new enterprise-level platform that empowers engineers to efficiently build low-code solutions for a wide variety of our customers' automated tasks. Designed in tandem with the CAP Design System, I worked with globally distributed teams to quickly create and validate solutions for our developers and engineers to implement.

...efficiently build low-code solutions that can be configured to meet diverse business needs across Conduent's client base.

Platform Capabilities

The Conduent Automation Platform (CAP) enables:

  • Workflow Automation: Drag-and-drop interface for creating complex business processes
  • Data Integration: Connect to multiple data sources and systems
  • Customizable Dashboards: Real-time monitoring and insights
  • User Management: Role-based access control and permissions

The platform significantly reduces development time for new solutions, enabling rapid deployment of customized workflows for clients across various industries.

...CAP Design System that provided a unified visual language and component library for both designers and developers.

Design System Integration

Working closely with the design system team, I:

  • Provided feedback on component needs from the product's perspective
  • Helped ensure components were flexible enough for diverse use cases
  • Documented unique patterns specific to the automation platform
  • Created custom components when needed while maintaining system consistency

This collaboration ensured visual consistency across the platform while allowing for specialized functionality required by complex workflows and data visualizations.

The Challenge

Creating an enterprise automation platform came with significant complexity challenges. We needed to design interfaces that could handle diverse business needs while remaining intuitive for users with varying technical backgrounds. Additionally, working with globally distributed teams required careful coordination and clear communication to ensure consistency across the platform.

...complexity challenges that required balancing powerful functionality with usability for users of varying technical expertise.

Design Complexity

Key challenges included:

  • Creating interfaces that could scale from simple to highly complex workflows
  • Designing data visualization tools that provided clarity without overwhelming users
  • Balancing technical functionality with accessibility for non-technical users
  • Supporting multiple use cases across various industries and business needs
  • Ensuring the system could grow and adapt to emerging requirements

The platform needed to be powerful enough for engineers while remaining approachable for business users who would configure and monitor workflows.

...globally distributed teams across different time zones, requiring careful coordination, clear documentation, and effective communication.

Cross-Team Collaboration

Working across distributed teams presented challenges:

  • Coordinating design feedback across multiple time zones
  • Managing transitions from tools like XD to Figma while maintaining productivity
  • Ensuring consistent understanding of requirements across all teams
  • Creating documentation that worked for both designers and developers
  • Navigating different working styles and approaches to design

As a senior designer, I often served as the bridge between different teams, helping to translate business needs into design solutions that could be effectively implemented by development teams.

The Process

My approach to designing this complex platform started with establishing design principles that would guide both designers and developers. I employed rapid multiple techniques to quickly validate ideas with stakeholders before moving to high-fidelity designs, ensuring alignment and efficiency throughout the development process.

...establishing design principles that would serve as guiding standards for the entire platform and help maintain consistency across various components.

Core Design Principles

I developed the following principles to guide our work:

  • Simplicity First: Keep interfaces clean and focused on essential tasks
  • Progressive Disclosure: Reveal complexity only as needed
  • Visual Clarity: Use consistent visual language to convey meaning
  • Scalable Patterns: Design solutions that work from simple to complex scenarios

These principles helped teams make consistent decisions when designing new features or addressing edge cases, ensuring the platform remained cohesive despite its complexity.

...multiple techniques to rapidly explore and validate ideas before investing time in high-fidelity designs, accelerating the feedback loop.

Rapid Ideation Process

Depending on the situation and needs, I provided early ideas in various mediums:

  1. Sharing photos of sketches on paper of multiple approaches
  2. Quick HTML/CSS prototypes to show functionality and interaction
  3. Quick Figma builds with existing components shared via video walkthroughs

These approaches allowed us to fail fast and pivot quickly, ensuring we didn't invest time in detailed designs for concepts that wouldn't work in practice. It was particularly valuable when designing complex components like the workflow builder, where interaction patterns needed to be intuitive yet powerful.

The Solution

The final product featured several key components designed to work together seamlessly: a powerful workflow builder, customizable dashboards, and intuitive user management. Each component was designed with flexibility in mind, allowing for adaptation to diverse business needs while maintaining consistency in the user experience.

...a powerful workflow builder that serves as the heart of the automation platform, enabling the creation of complex business processes through a visual interface.

Workflow Builder Design

The workflow builder was designed to:

  • Support drag-and-drop functionality for rapid workflow creation
  • Provide visual differentiation between node types (triggers, actions, conditions)
  • Include clear connection paths between workflow elements
  • Offer inline validation and error handling
  • Enable easy configuration through contextual panels

I worked closely with solution engineers to ensure the builder could handle complex business logic while remaining intuitive. The interface needed to balance power with usability, allowing technical teams to create sophisticated workflows without requiring custom coding.

...customizable dashboards that provide real-time insights into workflow performance and business metrics through configurable visualizations.

Dashboard Design System

For the dashboard component, I created:

  • Guidelines for chart selection based on data types and analysis goals
  • Color usage rules for consistent data visualization
  • Standardized layout patterns for filtering and reporting
  • Configurable widgets that could be arranged according to user preference
  • Responsive design patterns that worked across device sizes

The dashboard system needed to be flexible enough to serve both operational monitoring and executive reporting needs, with appropriate visualizations for different types of data and metrics.

...intuitive user management interfaces that simplify complex permission structures and role-based access control for enterprise environments.

User Management Design

For user management, I focused on:

  • Clear role definition and permission assignment
  • Simplified interfaces for common administrative tasks
  • Efficient search and filtering for large user bases
  • Visual indicators of user status and permissions

Following our design principle of "simplicity first," I kept these interfaces intentionally clean despite the complexity of enterprise permission systems. This approach made it easier for administrators to manage access without becoming overwhelmed by options.

Results & Impact

The CAP platform has been widely adopted across Conduent, becoming the foundation for numerous client solutions. The design system and component library have significantly reduced development time while maintaining consistency across the enterprise.

...foundation for numerous client solutions across multiple industries, driving efficiency and innovation.

Business Outcomes

Key business impacts included:

  • 40% faster solution deployment for client implementations
  • Expanded use across healthcare, financial services, and public sector
  • Increased reuse of components across multiple client solutions
  • Higher client satisfaction scores for implemented solutions
  • New revenue opportunities through platform capabilities

The platform has become a competitive advantage for Conduent, allowing the company to rapidly respond to market opportunities and deliver sophisticated automation solutions with greater efficiency.

...reduced development time by standardizing common patterns and components, allowing teams to focus on solving unique business problems.

Development Improvements

The platform achieved significant efficiency gains:

  • 40% reduction in UI development time through component reuse
  • Standardized testing procedures for common components
  • Faster onboarding for new designers and developers
  • Improved quality through consistent implementation patterns
  • Better collaboration between design and development teams

The design system had become a living resource that continued to evolve, with regular contributions as new patterns and solutions to common problems were discovered.

Lessons Learned

This multi-year project provided valuable insights into scaling design across complex enterprise systems. Working with global teams highlighted the importance of clear documentation and communication throughout the design process.

...scaling design across complex enterprise systems requires careful attention to both consistent patterns and targeted customization.

Enterprise Design Insights

Key lessons about scaling design included:

  • Building flexibility into base components pays dividends over time
  • Clear design principles become increasingly important as teams grow
  • Balancing standardization with innovation requires ongoing attention
  • Design systems must accommodate growth and unexpected use cases
  • Testing with real users across different use cases is essential

This experience reinforced the importance of creating systems that can scale logically rather than trying to anticipate every potential use case upfront—a "flexible design" approach that has proven valuable for the platform's ongoing development.

...clear documentation and communication are essential when working with distributed teams across different time zones and cultural contexts.

Communication Strategies

Effective approaches I developed included:

  • Creating video walkthroughs for complex interactions
  • Establishing component documentation templates
  • Implementing regular design review sessions across time zones
  • Using interactive prototypes to demonstrate behaviors
  • Developing shared terminology guidelines

These practices were particularly valuable in aligning cross-functional teams, reducing ambiguity in handoffs, and ensuring a consistent user experience across products and platforms. They also helped onboard new contributors more quickly and fostered a stronger sense of collaboration among designers and developers.

Conclusion

The Conduent Automation Platform represents a significant achievement in enterprise software design. By focusing on user needs while maintaining system flexibility, we created a platform that continues to evolve and adapt to new business requirements. The design principles and component library established during this project have become the foundation for Conduent's digital transformation efforts, enabling faster development cycles and more consistent user experiences.

As a Senior Product Designer on this project, I'm proud of the balance we struck between powerful functionality and intuitive user experience, proving that enterprise software doesn't have to sacrifice usability to deliver complex capabilities. This project showcases the value of thoughtful design in driving business efficiency and enabling technical teams to deliver better solutions for clients.

title: Facilities Management Products
content:
When I joined FM:Systems as the sole UX/Product Designer, I was both excited and a bit apprehensive. The opportunity to take full ownership of the design process was a challenge I was eager to tackle. From research and ideation to prototyping and implementation, I was responsible for every stage of product design.

Challenges and Growth:

Working solo meant balancing a wide array of tasks. I had to be not just a designer, but also a researcher, strategist, and sometimes even a project manager. This role pushed me to quickly adapt and learn, ensuring that I could handle the full spectrum of design responsibilities. The autonomy allowed me to refine my decision-making skills and become more resourceful, especially when navigating legacy products and multiple platforms.

Design Process:

My design process was user-centric and iterative. I began with thorough research, conducting user interviews and analyzing feedback to understand pain points and needs. I used these insights to inform my ideation phase, where I created wireframes and user flows using Sketch and Adobe XD. Prototyping was an integral part of my process, allowing me to test and refine designs before final implementation. Collaboration with the development teams was crucial to ensure that the designs were translated effectively into the final products.

Collaboration:

As the only designer, effective communication with other departments was crucial. I regularly collaborated with developers to ensure the feasibility of my designs, and I worked closely with product management to align the product's design with our north star.

Lessons Learned:

This experience taught me the importance of flexibility and adaptability. I learned to manage my time effectively, prioritize tasks, and maintain a clear focus on user needs while balancing business goals. The role also strengthened my problem-solving skills, as I often had to find creative solutions to complex design challenges.

Conclusion:

My time at FM:Systems was incredibly rewarding. As the sole UX/Product Designer, I was able to drive significant design improvements that positively impacted the company's products and user experience. This role not only deepened my design expertise but also prepared me for future challenges in the ever-evolving field of UX and Product Design.

Key Projects:

One of the most significant projects I worked on was a web-based mobile app called FM:Mobile. The goal was to develop a new modern mobile app to replace a legacy mobile app. Through user research, talking with and visiting maintenance technicians and supervisors, I learned about seeveral pain points within their workflow. Working closely with product management and engineering, I was able to quickly prototype and test potential solutions which led to the design and development of a new mobile solution with offline storage, a new notification system, and improved integration with our desktop-based facilities management product.

title: Customer Portal Navigation/IA
content:
Situation:

At the start of my tenure as a UX designer on Red Hat's award-winning Customer Portal, I was tasked with adding a link for an additional product section to one of the navigation dropdown menus. I realized this would be the eighth item in that menu, with several more products slated for addition soon after. Given the menu's current design, these additions would render the navigation unwieldy and user-unfriendly. Recognizing this issue, I proposed to my manager that a comprehensive redesign of the navigation was necessary. I offered to explore redesign options and received approval to proceed.

Task:

My task was to redesign the navigation system for the Customer Portal to accommodate the growing number of product sections while maintaining user-friendliness and efficiency. This involved analyzing the current navigation structure, researching best practices for complex menu systems, and developing a solution that would scale with the addition of new products. I needed to create a design that would improve the user experience while also being technically feasible to implement within our existing framework.

Action:

I began by working closely with our SEO specialist to analyze navigation usage and traffic patterns. I also partnered with product owners to identify areas they deemed most useful for users.

IAfter establishing a baseline for navigation usability, I designed a new navigation structure and information architecture for the Customer Portal. I conducted usability testing sessions with users from across the globe to test and quickly iterate on my proposed changes.

IOnce the design was thoroughly tested and finalized, I collaborated with our development team to implement the new navigation. Simultaneously, I worked with product teams across the organization to redesign their product pages, aiming to better surface information that users were seeking.

Result:

After implementing the new navigation and product pages, I continued to collaborate with our SEO specialist and product owners to monitor the effectiveness of the changes. The improvements I proposed and implemented yielded significant results:

  • 20% increase in traffic to content
  • Elevated visibility of important content—previously in the bottom 1%—to the top 50 pieces
  • 15% increase in time spent on site
  • 12% decrease in help requests
  • 20% increase in Google indexing due to the architectural changes
